reviewText:
This a reverse Tower-Defense game, the player controls the attacking units. I'll be honest, I went into this game expecting to hate it.  I'm happy that I was wrong and I offer my sincere apologies to '11-Bit Studios' for doubting you! A respectful bow and a tip of the hat to you! :)

This gem flew under the radar for lots of people. If you're a fan of the genre, you'll not be disappointed! The UI is very slick looking and responsive. It's also easy to pick-up and play thanks to a simple control scheme and well-done tutorial system. You can feel the passion, time, and quality, that the developers poured into this game. The production values alone are impressive. If you're just looking to have a good time and kick-back with a genre you know and love, stay the course! But If you've got a wii-touch of Sadism inside you that craves a seemingly unfair situation, like me, then the game has plenty of challenges to quench that hunger, too. Especially during that last couple of Campaign Missions.

That isn't to say, the game has no flaws. There are moments during the story, that are cliche and can be seen coming a mile away. While having a fully voiced cast can add a lot to a game experience, it only takes one person to ruin it. Certain cutscenes (seems like the unskippable ones?) move your camera/focus towards a scene on the other side of the map, without pausing the action. I've lost count of how many units have fallen in the line of cutscene-fire. A dislike of mine that probably doesn't bother anybody else, is the Commander's skill-set. The skills themselves are fine. It's the fact that the Commander is unable to offer any regular(gun) damage of his own. Even if it's just a tiny amount...every little bit, counts.

Since I don't wanna end this review on a sour note, I definatly recommend this game

reviewText:
ANOMALY WARZONE EARTH is surprisingly entertaining, with great tutorials. Its a top down somewhat tower defense game... only in reverse. You lead a squad of vehicles that must take clear cut streets through enemy defenses, but you select the route and your caravan just keeps following the path you set for them. So imagine a train that cannot stop on a tracks with multiple paths. If something blocks your train track, you divert your train at the next intersection by going to a tactical route map and just clicking on the intersection to point their next direction to head in. Its really as easy as that. You don't control the vehicles so much as just point out the route to take. You do have a player character to control. There is a 'speed up / turbo' button to make the game go faster.

Since you're going through a warzone, the enemy has turrets, and other defenses setup to slow you down. So this is like you play the part of a GPS and they'll do the fighting as they come upon enemies. You can buy more vehicles for your caravan, upgrade current vehicles (for the same price as buying them new) and assign their formations. Like do you select a less defensive more offensive vehicle to go first or do you select a more defensive less offensive vehicle? Another thing to consider is range of attack. The 'attack crawler' vehicle has a longer range, but it is considerably weaker than the 'defender APCs.' Eventually you'll get shielders that will provide a shield for the vehicles directly in front and in back of them in the caravan train. There are also tanks that you will unlock later. In all the game's player vehicles seem limited in diversity.

As a commander, you have abilities that you collect. The first is to repair your vehicles in a radius of where it is used for a specific time as the train keeps rolling. Your player character isn't limited to staying with the caravan, he can go out and wander to find things. This is a very simple yet engaging. The only downside is the controls could be better. A lot of times my commander was accidentally walking all over the place when I wanted him to repair things. Just because you hit the abilities menu, then select the ability with the mouse. Well when you use the mouse it makes your player character walk. The other abilities are, smoke screens that will cover vehicles in a radius preventing some cannons from hitting them and then decoys that will attract larger cannons that would otherwise accurately hit your vehicles in a smoke screen. Finally, there is a bomb target to bluntly bomb enemies. It might seem cheap, but it is useful for wide beam cannons that keep streaming a draining vehicles.

Eventually the challenge outweighs the fun just gets too much on even the normal difficulty. When you have limited resources, money and enemies keep getting more and more powerful, such as giving enemies a damage radius to every bullet and enemies that ressurect destroyed towers. Once one of your vehicles is destroyed, I find myself wanting restart from the last checkpoint, because I know that one vehicle down will make my train too weak to beat later levels.

Each level seems healthy time wise and you get to select your level of difficulty. It is definitely worth a play. Good instructions, good voice work explaining everything in a simple manner.

reviewText:
Anomaly: Warzone Earth is a reverse tower-defense strategy game, the first of the series.

The gameplay of Anomaly: Warzone Earth is very simple, yet needs lots of attention. You command your forces to destroy the enemy tower machine in your way. You will need to pick the best units combination then choose the best route for your troops to attack the enemy and then complete your objectives, but you can't just let your units attack alone like a rambo, your units are not in unlimited supply, you need to look after them. You can use some ability to help your troops destroy the enemy and survive the mission, like repair damaged units or call in airstrikes. Without these ability, your troops will surely get killed and you will fail, so keep an eye on them.

The graphics of Anomaly: Warzone Earth is beautiful, not so advanced, but very pleasing on the eye, perfectly crafted. From the UI to the battlefield, they're all good. This also comes with great performances.

This is one of the best tower-defense game I ever played. I recommend this!

reviewText:
A pretty nice game idea, playing like a reverse tower defence game, where instead of setting up towers and fighting off waves of enemies, you're navigating a small force of tanks and other vehicles into an enemy territory.

There's a lot of strategy involved here, as you must choose your routes carefully and to engage just enough towers at a time so not to get overwhelmed, whilst using abilities such as smoke screen and decoys to mislead enemy towers and protect your allies in the process. There are several different enemy towers, and each one can pose a serious threat if you don't approach it with good strategy. And in addition to encountering various tower setups, the game often throws other challenges your way too, such as needing to get across a bridge in the area before it gets destroyed, or having to evade powerful area artillery strikes from the enemy, and so on.

The game is really fun if you like tactical gameplay, but it's also pretty relentless and hard, even on Casual difficulty. If you're looking for a casual, relaxing game, you won't find it here. But if you're seeking a challenge, you'll be right at home. Unfortunately the game's checkpoint system can sometimes work against you. If you happened to reach a chekpoint when you're low on ability supplies and your vehicles are in poor shape, you might find yourself unable to make progress past the next area, and returning back to the previous section becomes impossible after a checkpoint. These times could cause you having to restart the whole level from the beginning.

In addition to the 14 campaign missions, you also get some bonus challenges (Baghdad Mayhem and Tokyo Raid) which you can try out, where you're given a series of tasks (not related to the story) in an area and you must complete them. Overall, the presentation is pretty good. Great visuals, adrenaline-pumping music, and nice voice acting. So if you don't mind some challenge, this game is worth getting.

reviewText: The premise behind Anomaly: Warzone Earth is that of reverse tower defense. Instead of setting up your defense towers in lanes and waiting for the enemy to attack, your job is to attack towers that have been set up by aliens through various campaign missions. While this may sound like it makes the tower  defense genre more interesting, and provides a much needed change in a fairly strict genre, the truth is, it does not. Graphically, it's serviceable. The developers did a decent job porting the game from mobile devices, even though there aren't that many options besides resolution. The artwork varies from creatively rendered post-apocalyptic cities around the world, to alien structures and weaponry. Voice acting is below average, but it isn't too bad. The British accent in particular sounds fake and over the top. As for the plot, it's your below average teenage action science fiction with very little substance and grossly lacking in twists. Overall,  Anomaly: Warzone Earth is predictable from beginning to end, if you can stomach finishing the game. From its presentation, to the mechanics, to the storyline, there isn't anything that rewards the player, or provides a sense of accomplishment and value. Playing the game feels more like an annoyance. It also suffers from a severe lack of depth and range. There are only four unit types, six enemy types, and only four commander abilities that can only be activated if you pick up their ability icons that are dropped on the map by supply planes. There is very little variation from mission to mission, and even though upgrading your units is an option, there is very little reason to do so, as you will need to get more units on the field instead. Having only one or two upgraded units go through the lanes is guaranteed suicide. Another very serious problem with Anomaly: Warzone Earth is the difficulty. Even at the easiest setting, there will be some more advanced campaign missions that are nearly impossible to beat unless you do exactly what the developers wanted you to by design. There is no choice to be made. Finishing those artificially difficult missions is not due to skill or through learned strategies, but by saving and repeating the same abilities you have been abusing of throughout the entire campaign. There is no strategy nor skill involved. You simply repeat the same steps over and over, for every mission. It doesn't really matter what enemies you are facing, or what the pointless mission objective is. The game gives you a false sense of decision making, and a false sense of strategy. It feels like all actions being done in-game are worthless and with no consequences. It's almost like the game plays itself. Only needing you to click a bit, instead of looking stupid as you poke your phone or your tablet, if you were playing on the game's original mobile platform. There are many other tower defense games that provide the player with actual choice of action and strategy. Anomaly: Warzone Earth does nothing to make the tower defense genre better. In fact, it makes it worse.\n\nAnomaly: Warzone Earth is mediocre.

So, what is Anomaly: Warzone Earth?
It's a tower defense game, but then again, is not: It's Tower Offense.

You get placed in charge of a squad consisting of up to 6 units and have to reach a certain point to complete each mission.

If not for that, then because of the fact you can change your squad's route mid-travel. Pop up strategic view, change a few turns, close it, boop, done.

If not for that, then for the story. Despite not being realistic, the story is plausible: a spaceship was toasted when it entered the atmosphere and, on impact cast giant energy domes around Bagdad and Tokyo - the Anomalies.

If not for that, then for the music. The music is really well-made, though... under all the radio chatter and gunfire, sometimes hard to discern.

And if not for that, then for the graphics. I don't know what engine the game is based on, but the graphics are a wonderful thing to behold. (Too bad my computer can't handle the higher settings.)

reviewText: I'm sure most of you guys are familiar with the term 'tower defense'. reviewText:
Wow! This is a great game. And this time I really didn't know what to expect at all from the game when I bought it. I just found the artstyle so appealing. I thought this would be another modern RTS game, this time with really stylish graphics that I'd enjoy to look at but never really gonna like to play ... but man was I wrong ...

At it's core Anomaly is a Tower Defense game. Only this time you're not playing the defending but the offending forces. So this time around you are playing a commander of a motorised squad that will attack the towers but can't be controlled directly by you. You can offcourse set the routes for your squad and you have some special abilities like repairing, laying smoke curtains to hide or placing decoys to protect your units and so on.

The style of the graphics, the sound, the music, the voice overs event the menus ... everything is blended perfectly alltogether to give a pretty unique gameplay experience of a sort I personally haven't encountered before.

This game sucks you right in from the first minute because of its very unique style and easy accessibility featuring perfect XBox 360 controller support. Even the story is nicely spread out through the campaign. On top of that it seems to feature a good portion of replayability by offering a ton of missions: First there is the story mode, then there are two campaigns based on locations from the story mode and after that you can still play on in some bonus missions with extra difficulty and slight twitches to the original gameplay mechanics.

I liked very much what I've seen unti now and I can wholeheartedly recommend you to buy this game, exspecially when it's on sale. But I must say (and I don't say this often) this game is even worth it's full price. So go on and get it if you're in for some thrilling action strategy sort of game you haven't seen anywhere else before.

reviewText:
A very refreshing take on the tower defense series.

The graphics are really good, and the music is pretty driving as well. The voice acting is good as well, other than the HORRIBLE fake Japanese accents. How hard is it to find someone with an actual Japanese accent?

Superficial stuff aside, the gameplay is really solid. It's a blast having to manage your team, forming a good balance between offense and defense, planning your route strategically, all while using your commander to jump into the fray to heal units or call in strikes without getting him killed. It's really a welcome layer of strategy on top of the (what I consider to be) tedious tower defense genre.

What didn't work so much for me was how the game seems to demand perfection. Granted, that's pretty much the tower defense genre anyway, but I was hoping this game would take a step backwards in that regard. If you lose even one of your units, not only will you most likely not have the resources needed to replace it, but you will be facing a DRASTICALLY harder battle. Borderline impossible, on any difficulty other than casual.

Unfortunately, that means you will be doomed to replay the same mission over and over until you find the perfect formula for success.

I am not a fan of games that devolve that way, but I genuinely enjoyed this one. I didn't play any of the extra modes though, as I was mostly done with it by the time I replayed the final mission for the 2-dozenth time.

My suggestion is to give a rating to the tower defense genre as a whole on a scale of 1-100 and add 20 points to it. If you like/love tower defense games, you will enjoy this. If you are meh about them, you will still probably enjoy this. If you have never found a tower defense game that you really liked, then only pick this up in a massive sale.

The best Anomaly out of the bunch IMO.

Great controller support.
Great graphics.
Great gameplay.
Above average voice over and story.

It's a tower defence to put it blunt. But instead of defending your base, your constantly moving into enemy territory and defending your tanks and crew.
This leads to some great tactical gameplay on the fly. You can 'pause' and alter set routes, and summon or upgrade without the worry of being 'on the clock'.

Would rec for novice and hardcores since it has multiple difficulties.

7/10

DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review, if you want a full review, then please read better reviews then mine
Anomaly Warzone Earth is the first in a line up of great Sci-Fi/Action/Strategy games. You plan your route carefully with planning and thought, after you get to choose the loadout of vehicles you wish, after you try and survive the terrors of the Alien lifeforms which has taken over Baghdad and other ares round that part. Overall it makes me feel like I am playing a tower defense game, but instead of planning to defend whatever I need, I am actually moving through, while the Alien lifeforms is planning its way on defending either its power cores or just trying to ruin your day by just shooting you non-stop. Overall the graphics and music are great, the voice acting is good and the story is actually quite a good story, kinda weird as I was just expecting soldiers trying to move their way through either a group of terrorists or shooting their way through to get out of Baghdad, like Jagged Alliance or Doorkickers.

The game is great, short, but challenging as you may die a lot for poor planning, but thankfully their is a good checkpoint system where if you die or want to start over again, you can just start from the checkpoint. A great first game from 11 Bit Studios!

RECOMMENDED :)

This game's simplicity seems to be the cause of its excellence. That is, the game is uncomplicated enough that you can easily see the results of your choices: Maybe you need a unit with longer range? At the time, Anomaly warzone earth was unique game in the market. Abandoning the traditional tower defence gameplay that we are familiar with, it places players in the role of the attacking force against defending towers.

Story is decent. Set in the near future, alien spacecrafts have landed in major cities around the world. Anomalies are created in these areas, which affect satellites and radars around the globe. You play as the commander of 14th platoon sent to discover the the affects of these anomalies and deal with the threats in the area.

Gameplay is a mix of strategy and tactics. Before each level, you can select the types of troops you can bring in as well as upgrading their stats (which is capped at certain level). A map is also displayed which indicates the the roads and tower placements in the area. You need to arrange the best route to reach the objective and go through the least number of towers possible (if you want to preserve your unit's health). When you begin the map, your units will spawn in and begin following the route you created before. At any time, you can go back to the map screen again and change the pathing of your units. The next component of the game is managing your troops. You play as a commander (who can't attack), whose role is to basically protect you units units. There are a number of abilities which are avialble which allows you to either reduce damage dealt to your troops or heal them up. The defensive abilities will create a mark on the map indicating the area which your units will gain the benefits in. Other abilities are more offensive, such as airstrikes, which deal damage to towers. As a unit yourself on the battlefield, you also have health, which when depleted means that you unable to move for a while before respawning again. Units and towers also have health which is indicated by a bar above their model. When you lose all you troops (and unable to create more), the game ends.

There are few game modes available. First off is the campaign, which takes you to different locations as you deal with the invading aliens. Other modes are unlocked from completing the campaign.

Graphics are good. Unit models and textures are well done. The environment also does a great job at instilling 'warzone' feeling with all the destroyed buldings and debris.

Audio is excellent. The voice acting is well done. Sound effects from explosions and gun fire are good as well.

reviewText: Anomaly: Warzone Earth is a decent escort mission based game. An alien invasion has taken over the planet and this select British team is here to save the world. The player controls a commander who is on foot and escorts a squad of up to six vehicles and helps defend them while taking out the enemy. The vehicles are the primary offense against the horde of alien turrets blocking their path. The commander can utilize four different abilities which include a decoy, smokescreen, healing, and an air strike, however you must collect tokens to enable those abilities and are typically given a small stash before each mission begins. The abilities are stackable so you can place as many as you want provided you have enough tokens. He can also purchase additional vehicles using money collected by destroying turrets or shooting crystals. Vehicle position and route planning are vital and can be managed while the action is paused. Each vehicle also has three upgrade points that cost money which give it more offensive punch plus additional armor.\n\nIt is a short game of about 4-5 hours. It offers two primary campaigns and a final boss battle. There are also a couple extra missions beyond the story mode. It is a solid game that doesn't offer a whole lot of depth, but it's simplicity is one of it's major strengths. It's a nice spin on the traditional tower defense genre that could open the door for better games of this type in the future.

It's a tower defence game with a twist, which is that you are the convoy going against the towers. The gameplay is fairly simple and yet it retains enough compelling strategy to be worth playing. You basically have to plot a route that is most survivable, while gathering most resources. You have control over a commander, who can move anywhere on the battlefield and he is your only means of interaction, enabling you to boost the health of your convoy whilst dropping smoke and calling in air strikes. There are also vehicle upgrades to earn. The convoy appears to move slowly, but you are constantly being set goals and needing to take your eye off it in order to send your commander off on his own. Extra challenging elements are thrown in, such as airborn friendlies plotting their own course across the map.\n\nGraphically and sonically, the game is really quite impressive. Overall it isn't the most amazing game you'll ever play, but it succeeds in being fun and providing a good mix of strategic forward planning with realtime action. The main source of irritation I have found is that there is no save game feature; only a checkpoint system. There's no way to rewind back past the most recent checkpoint. Occasionally, the game surprises you with something you couldn't anticipate and you realise that your strategy up to that point won't enable you to finish the level, which means you have to start again from the very beginning.

The reverse TD aspect of this game (You play the creeps instead) is very well presented and doesn't outstay its welcome. The interface and controls are slick and fluid, and feel very natural. Game wasn't bad, but design flaws started coming up later in the game. It is fun how its the reverse of TD, and you can change your route. It would have been nicer if there was more of a variety of units, as things like the tank is just a straight upgrade of the starting APC, and the dragon can attack 2 sides, but does less damage and has much less range than tank and crawler....so seems not as useful. The problem was, design problems keep from the game from being better. The game says you can change and pick your path, but then uses a unit that will kill your entire squad if you go towards it in the path you are guarding. So there may be 4 paths, but because of the unit you can only use 2 paths, which is kind of a lame attempt at pretending you have more options than you actually do. Also, you get multiple different items, which is fun because you can use different things to get past towers. But then the game shoots itself in the foot and just introduces powerful towers that smoke doesn't work on and bombs don't kill, meaning only your decoy works. So to make new towers completely ignore half my abilities means I no longer have options, and just have to hoard and only hope for 1 specific type of power, which is lame. This means your smoke only helps with starter towers, which is dumb because later in the game they barely do anything anyways. Then the game introduces towers that if you use powers (which you have to to survive) can resurrect all the other towers you killed, which is super dumb. Also the tower has super long range, so avoiding it won't actually do anything. Things like that isn't adding a new layer, its just stacking the deck much more in the opponents favor. This is why you basically have to play easy later in the game. Also the pathfinding is super stupid. You have to plan your own path, but countless times I have gotten past the part I planned, only to realize the path the game was auto taking me was straight up towards a tower that autokills you if you go straight towards, and since you can't turn around (dumb exclusion) you auto die. Other times the auto path would take me in a square, just going in circles, or towards a giant cluster of guys instead of an open area. Since maps are huge you can't be asked to plan everything, especially since there are multiple parts in the game the game uses non-tower mechanics to force you even more down a specific way or away from a certain way. It's not too much to ask to have the game not purposefully go the worst way possible every time, especially since you get caught up in battle and its hard to see the way you are planning to go sometimes. The extras missions are overly hard and kind of dumb since they take away the main point of the main game. Also the levels get kind of repeitive and devolve into the same thing.  7/10.

reviewText: Anomaly: Warzone Earth is a decent escort mission based game. An alien invasion has taken over the planet and this select British team is here to save the world. The player controls a commander who is on foot and escorts a squad of up to six vehicles and helps defend them while taking out the enemy. The vehicles are the primary offense against the horde of alien turrets blocking their path. The commander can utilize four different abilities which include a decoy, smokescreen, healing, and an air strike, however you must collect tokens to enable those abilities and are typically given a small stash before each mission begins. The abilities are stackable so you can place as many as you want provided you have enough tokens. He can also purchase additional vehicles using money collected by destroying turrets or shooting crystals. Vehicle position and route planning are vital and can be managed while the action is paused. Each vehicle also has three upgrade points that cost money which give it more offensive punch plus additional armor.\n\nIt is a short game of about 4-5 hours. It offers two primary campaigns and a final boss battle. There are also a couple extra missions beyond the story mode. It is a solid game that doesn't offer a whole lot of depth, but it's simplicity is one of it's major strengths. It's a nice spin on the traditional tower defense genre that could open the door for better games of this type in the future.
